title: Framework Computer
content:
{{Short description|American computer company}}
{{Multiple issues|
{{Self-published|date=October 2022}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2022}}
{{Overly detailed|date=January 2022}}
}}

[[File:Framework laptop part made with love by team.jpg|thumb|Framework team member's names printed on a part of the Framework Laptop.]]

'''Framework Computer Inc''' is an American laptop manufacturer.<ref name="pcmag">{{Cite web |last1=Buzzi |first1=Matthew |last2=Burek |first2=John |date=August 25, 2021 |title=Framework Laptop Review |url=https://www.pcmag.com/reviews/framework-laptop |website=[[PCMAG]]}}</ref><ref name="tomsguide">{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomsguide.com/reviews/framework-laptop-review-the-anti-macbook-has-arrived|title=Framework Laptop review: The anti-MacBook has arrived|first=Alex|last=Wawro|date=August 18, 2021|website=Tom's Guide}}</ref><ref name="arstechnica">{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2021/07/frameworks-new-lightweight-modular-laptop-delivers-on-its-promises/|title=Review: Framework's lightweight modular laptop is a winner|first=Jim|last=Salter|date=July 27, 2021|website=Ars Technica}}</ref><ref name="cnet">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/framework-laptop-review-a-functional-and-futureproof-13-inches/|title=Framework Laptop review: A functional and futureproof 13 inches|first=Lori|last=Grunin|date=July 22, 2021|website=CNET}}</ref> The company positions itself as a proponent of the [[electronics right to repair]] movement,<ref name="ft">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/e1e6d16c-4e0b-45a9-8007-95da916341f0|title=Why Big Tech should embrace the 'right to repair' revolution|website=www.ft.com|first1=Dave|last1=Lee|date=August 31, 2021}}</ref><ref name="freethink">{{Cite web|url=https://www.freethink.com/series/challengers/right-to-repair|title=This DIY laptop is challenging tech giants like Apple & Microsoft|website=www.freethink.com|author=Freethink Team|date=October 16, 2021}}</ref><ref name="makezine"/> and their laptops are designed to be easy to disassemble, with replaceable parts.<ref name="pcmag"/><ref name="tomsguide"/> The company's approach has earned them praise from [[Louis Rossmann]],<ref name="LouisRossmann">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2YjKYG8P58|title=Frame.work isn't virtue signalling; they genuinely support Right to Repair. I wish them success.|first1=Louis|last1=Rossmann|date=July 23, 2021|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="LouisRossmann-schematics">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8cJj8PUY0DU|title=Framework laptop finally embraces "schematics or die", long live framework!|first1=Louis|last1=Rossmann|date=May 13, 2022|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> [[Linus Sebastian]], the latter having invested $224,998.37 into the company, and [[Cory Doctorow]].<ref name="CoryDoctorow-2021">{{Cite web|url=https://pluralistic.net/2021/09/21/monica-byrne/#think-different|title=The Framework is the most exciting laptop I've ever used|first1=Cory|last1=Doctorow|date=September 21, 2021|website=pluralistic.net}}</ref><ref name="CoryDoctorow-2022">{{Cite web|url=https://pluralistic.net/2022/11/13/graceful-failure/#frame|title=The Framework is the most exciting laptop I've ever broken|first1=Cory|last1=Doctorow|date=November 13, 2022|website=pluralistic.net}}</ref> In November 2021, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine listed the Framework Laptop on their list of the 100 Best Inventions of 2021.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://time.com/collection/best-inventions-2021/6112625/framework-laptop/|title=A Notebook You Can Repair: Framework Laptop|first=Don|last=Steinberg|date=November 10, 2021|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> In March 2022, ''[[Fast Company]]'' listed the Framework Laptop on their list of the Most Innovative Companies of 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90722815/framework-innovative-laptop-easy-repair-electronics|title=How Framework is helping fix our unsustainable electronics industry|first=Jared|last=Newman|date=March 8, 2022|work=[[Fast Company]]}}</ref>

== History ==

In January 2020, the company was founded by Nirav Patel, who was the original Head of Hardware at [[Reality Labs|Oculus]].<ref name="makezine" /><ref name="freethink" /><ref>{{Cite web |date=2014-03-26 |title=The superfast rise of Oculus VR: How it went from startup to $2B acquisition in 21 months (interview) |url=https://venturebeat.com/games/the-accelerated-life-of-oculus-vr-interview/ |access-date=2023-05-17 |website=VentureBeat |language=en-US}}</ref> In the first half 2021, the company was funded with a $9 million [[seed money|seed round]].<ref name="framework-pitch-series-a">{{Cite web|url=https://pitch.com/presentations/Framework-Pitch-Deck-3mETzR4VNkQP5ncnEk0eS8Kk?slide=472d36fd-f50e-49d2-9b4d-a0396debadf8|title=Framework Pitch Deck by @framework - Pitch|publisher=Framework|date=May 24, 2022|website=Pitch}}</ref><ref name="anorak-post">{{Cite web|url=https://www.anorak.vc/post/why-i-invested-in-framework|title=Why I invested in Framework|first=Greg|last=Castle|date=Jun 21, 2021|website=Anorak Ventures}}</ref> Linus Sebastian announced in September 2021 that he would be investing $224,998.37 into the company,<ref name="linus-tech-tips-disclose">{{Cite web|publisher=Linus Tech Tips|title=I'm Legally Obligated to Disclose This|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LSxbc1IN9Gg|date=September 15, 2021|via=www.youtube.com|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|publisher=Linus Tech Tips |date=2023-03-26 |title=I Made a Bad Decision – Framework Investment Update |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UeCdBVHYa_8 |via=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> after having previously praised the 11th Gen Intel Framework Laptop 13.<ref name="linus-tech-tips-review">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0rkTgPt3M4k|title=A Completely Upgradeable Laptop? - Framework Laptop Review|author=Linus Tech Tips|date=July 26, 2021|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> In January 2022, the company raised an additional $18 million of financing in a [[series A round|series A]] round, led by [[Spark Capital]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/blog/frameworks-series-a-and-the-years-ahead|title=Framework's Series A and the Years Ahead|date=January 27, 2022|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="techcrunch-series-a">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/02/01/framework-looks-to-expand-repairability-beyond-the-laptop/|title=Framework looks to expand repairability beyond the laptop|date=February 1, 2022|website=TechCrunch}}</ref><ref name="framework-pitch-series-a" />

==Products==

=== Framework Laptop 13 ===

[[File:Framework laptop sway community forum small.png|thumb|Framework Laptop]]
In July 2021, Framework began fulfillment of their first product, the Framework Laptop (retroactively the Framework Laptop 13), with an 11th Gen Intel Core i5 or i7 chip to the [[United States|US]] and [[Canada]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/blog/the-framework-laptop-is-now-shipping-and-press-reviews|title=The Framework Laptop is now shipping, and press reviews are up!|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> In December 2021, Framework opened pre-orders to the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Germany]] and [[France]].<ref name="frame.work-pre-order-uk-germany-france">{{Cite web|date=December 16, 2021|url=https://frame.work/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-uk-germany-and-france|title=Now Available for Pre-order in UK, Germany, and France|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> In February 2022, pre-ordering became available for [[Ireland]], [[Austria]] and [[Netherlands|The Netherlands]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Patel|first=Nirav|date=2022-02-22|title=Bringing the Framework Laptop to more of the world|url=https://frame.work/nl/en/blog/bringing-the-framework-laptop-to-more-of-the-world|access-date=2022-02-23|website=Framework|language=en}}</ref> The Framework Laptop received a 10 out of 10 in [[iFixit|iFixit's]] repairability score.<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 28, 2021|title=Framework Laptop Teardown: 10/10, But is it Perfect?|url=https://www.ifixit.com/News/51614/framework-laptop-teardown-10-10-but-is-it-perfect|website=iFixit|language=en}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/apr/13/framework-laptop-review-a-modular-pc-easy-to-fix-or-upgrade Framework Laptop review: a modular PC easy to fix or upgrade] The Guardian. 2022.</ref> The standard Framework Laptop ships as a fully assembled laptop, while the Framework Laptop [[Do_it_yourself|DIY]] Edition ships with the RAM, storage, operating system, and in 11th Gen, the WiFi module uninstalled. All of these modules can be ordered with the DIY edition for an additional fee, or left out and purchased separately.

In May 2022, the company launched their second generation Framework Laptop with a 12th Gen Intel Core i5 or i7 chip that ships with an upgraded back panel, alongside their 12 Gen Upgrade Kit, to allow 11th Gen users to upgrade their laptops. In September 2022, pre-ordering became available for [[Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Now available for pre-order in Australia |url=https://frame.work/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref>

In September 2022, the company launched a [[Chromebook]] edition based on their 12th Gen Intel model for $999. Unlike the standard laptop, the Chromebook's specifications is fixed to an i5-1240P, 8GB of RAM and a 256GB SSD - but it retains the same upgradability as the standard laptop. Framework claims that the Chromebook edition has upgraded speakers and batteries compared to the standard laptop - but the speakers were described as "muffled" by ZDnet and the battery life was rated as quite poor for a Chromebook by ZDnet, Engadget and PCMag. Engadget and PCMag criticise the price relative to other Chromebooks, but the former states that given the hardware it seems fair. <ref name="chromeunboxed-framework-chromebook">{{Cite web|url=https://chromeunboxed.com/framework-laptop-chromebook-edition-google-chrome-os/|title=Google and Framework partner up to launch a fully-modular Chromebook|first=Robby|last=Payne|date=September 21, 2022|website=Chrome Unboxed}}</ref><ref name="zdnet-chromebook">{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/frameworks-new-chromebook-laptop-pieces-together-the-best-of-both-worlds/|title=Framework's new Chromebook laptop pieces together the best of both worlds|first=June|last=Wan|date=September 21, 2022|website=ZDNET}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Chin |first=Monica |date=2022-09-21 |title=Framework’s new Chromebook is upgradable and customizable |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/9/21/23363862/framework-laptop-chromebook-edition-laptop-design-specs-price-release |access-date=2023-05-17 |website=The Verge |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Hear me out: The modular Framework Chromebook is worth the $1,000 (for some) |url=https://www.engadget.com/framework-modular-repairable-chromebook-review-173035156.html |access-date=2023-05-17 |website=Engadget |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Framework Laptop Chromebook Edition Review |url=https://www.pcmag.com/reviews/framework-laptop-chromebook-edition |access-date=2023-05-17 |website=PCMAG |language=en}}</ref>

In March 2023, a third-generation laptop was announced, featuring [[Raptor Lake|13th Gen Intel Core]] and [[Ryzen#Ryzen_7000|Ryzen 7040]] processors. The series of the Framework Laptop with a 13.5-inch display was renamed as Framework Laptop 13.<ref name="framework-next-level-2023">{{Citation |last=Patel |first=Nirav |title=Framework Next Level Event - 2023 Launch Event|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ccpsyRipHlk |date=2023-03-23 |access-date=2023-03-23 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="pcworld-next-level">{{Cite web|title=Framework's Latest Laptops Add AMD & Discrete GPU Options|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w07c80xoc5w|date=2023-03-25|access-date=2023-03-29 |author=PCWorld|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref>

==== Motherboard ====

In April 2022, the company partly open sourced their [[motherboard]] with [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] and electrical documentation,<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 18, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rjUlznKioo&t=300s|title=The Download: New Job, New Channel, DALL-E 2, Framework Laptop and more|author=GitHub|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="arstechnica-mainboard">{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/04/framework-will-sell-you-its-laptop-motherboard-without-the-laptop-for-399/|title=Buy the Framework laptop's $399 motherboard to make your own mini PC|first=Andrew|last=Cunningham|date=April 22, 2022|website=Ars Technica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=May 1, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1B1ooz5aSU|title=The Framework Mainboard Case! Printed, Built, Tested.|author=Elevated Systems|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="LouisRossmann-schematics" /> being available in their [[marketplace]], giving away 100 motherboards to makers and developers.<ref name="frame.work-mainboard">{{Cite web|date=April 18, 2022|url=https://frame.work/blog/mainboard-availability-and-open-source-release|title=Mainboard Availability and Open Source Release|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="hackaday-mainboard">{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/04/21/modular-laptop-maker-provides-mainboard-documentation-for-non-laptop-projects/|title=Modular Laptop Maker Provides Mainboard Documentation For Non-Laptop Projects|first=Ryan|last=Flowers|date=April 21, 2022|website=Hackaday}}</ref>

There is an issue with the first generation motherboard with 11th Gen Intel Core, that requires complete removal and reconnection of both main battery and [[real-time clock|RTC]] coin cell battery, if the laptop is not charged for a relatively short period of time.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 7, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/laptop-wont-power-on-unless-i-plug-in-ac-power/13085/61|title=Laptop won't power on unless i plug in AC power|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yeokhengmeng.com/2021/09/review-usage-and-repair-of-the-framework-laptop/|title=Review, usage and repair of the Framework laptop|website=yeokhengmeng.com|author=Yeo Kheng Meng|date=September 21, 2021|access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref> The company said that the issue is by 11th Gen Intel Core silicon bug, and they would work to swap out a replacement [[real-time clock|RTC]] coin cell battery or 11th Gen motherboard to the people seeing the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 15, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/rtc-viability-of-using-a-rechargable-rtc-battery/17664/43|title=RTC: Viability of using a rechargable RTC battery|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref name="linus-tech-tips-first-generation-rtc-battery">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U5YOjLdfRZA&t=5958s|title=It's Coming For Us... - WAN Show June 17, 2022 - Framework transparency|author=Linus Tech Tips|date=June 17, 2022|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref>

==== Firmware ====

Framework Laptop uses a proprietary [[BIOS]] firmware, InsydeH2O [[UEFI]] [[BIOS]] by [[Insyde Software]]<ref>{{Cite web|date=August 9, 2021|url=https://www.insyde.com/press_news/press-releases/insyde%C2%AE-software-powers-newly-launched-framework%E2%84%A2-modular-laptop|title=Insyde® Software Powers Newly Launched Framework™ Modular Laptop|website=Insyde Software}}</ref> and an open sourced [[embedded controller]] (EC) firmware based on CrOS EC<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform/ec/+/HEAD/README.md|title=CrOS EC (Embedded Controller)|website=chromium.googlesource.com}}</ref> by Framework. In April 2021, the company mentioned that open source firmware was well aligned to their mission.<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 11, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/free-the-ec-and-coreboot-only/791/5|title=Coreboot on the Framework Laptop|website=community.frame.work|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> In January 2022, the company open sourced their EC firmware.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/01/framework-put-up-the-source-code-for-their-embedded-controller-firmware/|title=Framework put up the source code for their Embedded Controller firmware|first=Liam|last=Dawe|date=January 21, 2022|via=www.gamingonlinux.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=January 21, 2022|url=https://frame.work/blog/open-sourcing-our-firmware|title=Open Sourcing our Firmware|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> The company modifies the BIOS source code they bought from [[Insyde Software]] to meet their specific BIOS needs. The company's [[Linux]] Vendor Firmware Service (LVFS) with [[fwupd]] is in testing state.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fwupd.org/lvfs/devices/work.frame.Laptop.TGL.BIOS.firmware|title=LVFS Framework Laptop TGL|website=fwupd.org|access-date=May 12, 2022}}</ref> Framework Laptop Chromebook Edition uses an open source [[BIOS]] firmware, [[coreboot]].<ref name="9to5google-framework-chromebook-coreboot">{{Cite web|first=Abner|last=Li|date=September 21, 2022|url=https://9to5google.com/2022/09/21/google-framework-chromebook/|title=Google and Framework making an upgradable Chromebook, starting at $999|website=9to5Google}}</ref>

{| class="wikitable"
|+ BIOS firmware on the motherboards
|-
! Motherboard !! BIOS product !! Upstream BIOS vendor !! Initial BIOS version !! Latest BIOS version
|-
| 11th Gen [[Intel Core]] || InsydeH2O UEFI BIOS || [[Insyde Software]] || 3.02 || 3.17<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/framework-laptop-bios-releases-S1dMQt6F|title=Framework Laptop BIOS and Driver Releases (11th Gen Intel® Core™)|website=knowledgebase.frame.work|access-date=April 11, 2023}}</ref>
|-
| 12th Gen [[Intel Core]] || InsydeH2O UEFI BIOS || [[Insyde Software]] || 3.04 || 3.04 or 3.05<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/framework-laptop-bios-and-driver-releases-12th-gen-intel-core-Bkx2kosqq|title=Framework Laptop BIOS and Driver Releases (12th Gen Intel® Core™)|website=knowledgebase.frame.work|access-date=October 30, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-11-21 |title=[SOLVED] Is it normal that my 12th-gen laptop has a v3.05 BIOS? |url=https://community.frame.work/t/solved-is-it-normal-that-my-12th-gen-laptop-has-a-v3-05-bios/24928/22 |access-date=2023-04-21 |website=Framework Community |language=en}}</ref>
|-
| 12th Gen [[Intel Core]] Chromebook Edition || [[coreboot]]<ref name="9to5google-framework-chromebook-coreboot" /> || || ||
|}

==== Battery life ====

The initial 55Wh battery has been described as middling.<ref name="arstechnica" /><ref name=elevated-systems-6months-review>{{Cite web|date=February 27, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fNYZkqIn8rg|title=Framework Laptop 6 Months Later. I'm Less Impressed|author=Elevated Systems|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> This feedback was addressed with the release of a 61Wh battery, available as an option in the 2023 edition of the laptop.<ref name="framework-next-level-2023" /> An Ars Technica review found that the battery life of the 13th Gen Intel motherboard was significantly improved over prior designs, gaining a 40% uplift in [[PCMark]]'s battery test but remaining mostly the same when running [[Handbrake]] - this is despite the reviewer testing battery life with the 55Wh battery from their previous machine, with an upgrade to the 61Wh battery the runtime improved by another 13%.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cunningham |first=Andrew |date=2023-05-16 |title=Review: Framework Laptop’s 13th-gen Intel upgrade helps fix its battery problem |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/05/review-framework-laptops-13th-gen-intel-upgrade-helps-fix-its-battery-problem/ |access-date=2023-05-17 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}}</ref>

The battery drains even in a complete shut down state within [[BIOS]] version 3.07 or earlier with the 11th [[Intel Core]] [[motherboard]],<ref>{{Cite web|date=January 18, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/battery-slowly-drains-when-completely-shut-down/13923|title=Battery slowly drains when completely shut down|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> later fixed in BIOS unofficial version 3.08.<ref name="twitter-framework-20220610">{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/FrameworkPuter/status/1535041802125729792|title=Framework on Twitter|publisher=Framework|date=June 10, 2022|via=twitter.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=April 14, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/is-there-something-wrong-with-the-3-08-bios/17509/|title=Is there something wrong with the 3.08 BIOS?|website=community.frame.work}}</ref>

=== Framework Laptop 16 ===
Framework Laptop 16 is a larger laptop unveiled at the promotional ''Next Level'' keynote in March 2023. It is dubbed the “holy grail” of upgradeable laptops for engineers and gamers due to the new expansion bay that can attach PCIe components such as a dedicated GPU, as well as adapt the laptop's cooling system.<ref name="framework-next-level-2023" />

==== Technical specifications ====
As most components in Framework products are designed to be reconfigurable, this table lists stock specifications available at the time of purchase.

=== Expansion Cards ===

A core feature of the Framework Laptop is the Expansion Card system that provides the primary input/output for the laptop.
In its base form, the laptop is equipped with recessed slots containing USB-C ports that can be used directly. These slots can be attached with an assortment of interchangeable cards that add features such as USB-C, USB-A, DisplayPort 1.4, HDMI 2.0b, 256GB storage expansion, 1TB storage expansion, MicroSD, and 2.5GbE Ethernet<ref>{{Cite web |title=Fix Consumer Electronics |url=https://frame.work/marketplace/expansion-cards |access-date=2022-08-30 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref> 
The Framework Laptop 13 can accommodate four expansion cards, increased to six on the Framework Laptop 16.
The company launched the Expansion Card Developer Program to open card development to the public: releasing documentation, [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] templates, and reference designs for Expansion Cards—all under open source licenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/FrameworkComputer/ExpansionCards|title=Reference designs and documentation to create Expansion Cards for the Framework Laptop|via=github.com|author=Framework Computer}}</ref>

== Marketplace ==

The Framework Marketplace is an online store service hosted on the Framework website that primarily sells parts and tools that can be used to upgrade and repair the Framework Laptop. These include but are not limited to, replacement motherboards, batteries, entire screen assemblies, RAM and storage drives. The Marketplace also sells customization parts, including screen bezels, keyboard layouts, and expansion cards.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Carbon Capture |url=https://frame.work/products/carbon-capture |access-date=2022-08-30 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref>

== Third party projects ==

[[File:Mainboard-terminal-heroshot.jpg|thumb|Mainboard Terminal, a retro-style round display PC that uses the Framework's [[motherboard]] with Ubuntu.]]
[[File:Framedeck framework logo.jpg|thumb|Framedeck, a Framework [[motherboard]] based cyberdeck with clear acrylic and brass influenced by [[TRS-80 Model 100]].]]
[[File:Framework Tablet Complete Build.jpg|thumb|Framework-Tablet, a 3D printable tablet case for Framework Laptop.]]

Third party companies and individuals make their projects<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 16, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/a-company-or-individual-driven-projects/18559|title=Company or individually driven projects|website=community.frame.work|access-date=May 17, 2022}}</ref><ref name="gizmodo-mods">{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/these-framework-laptop-mods-show-us-exactly-why-modular-1848341702|title=These Framework Laptop Mods Show Us Exactly Why Modular Computers Are So Damn Cool|date=January 17, 2022|website=Gizmodo}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2023/01/26/all-about-usb-c-framework-laptop/|title=All About USB-C: Framework Laptop|date=January 26, 2023|website=Hackaday}}</ref> in a Framework [[software ecosystem|ecosystem]].

In December 2022, Framework joined the 3D printing database site, Printables.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.printables.com/|title=3D models database - Printables.com|website=www.printables.com}}</ref> as a brand, highlighting the community projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/12/framework-noctua-and-other-brands-add-official-3d-models-to-printables/|title=Framework, Noctua, and other brands add official 3D models to Printables|first=Kevin|last=Purdy|date=December 20, 2022|website=Ars Technica}}</ref>

=== Motherboard based ===

* CJ64, a cyberdeck-like keyboard [[personal computer|PC]] that re-purposes the Framework Laptop's [[motherboard]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/CJ-Elevated/Project_CJ64|title=CJ-Elevated/Project_CJ64: The Framework Mainboard Project CJ64 enclosure |via=github.com|author= Elevated Systems|access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VeYfKu9KlTg|title=Complete PC in a Mechanical Keyboard! Retro Concept, Modern Hardware.|via=www.youtube.com|author=Elevated Systems|date=November 7, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ewVp96JN0nQ|title=The Ultimate Framework Keyboard PC! Machined Aluminum Mainboard Enclosure!|via=www.youtube.com|author=Elevated Systems|date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/framework-keyboard-cyberdeck|title=Framework Laptop Mainboard Powers Custom 60% Mechanical Keyboard|date=November 11, 2021|website=Tom's Hardware}}</ref><ref name="gizmodo-mods" />
* Mainboard Terminal, a retro-style round display [[personal computer|PC]] that uses the Framework Laptop's [[motherboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/penk/MainboardTerminal|title=penk/MainboardTerminal: Mainboard Terminal - A Retro-style Computer with a Modern Core|via=github.com|author=Penk Chen|access-date=May 10, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/framework-mainboard-modular-circular-cyberdeck|title=Sensational Circular-Screened Cyberdeck Hides Modular Intel 11th Gen PC|date=May 10, 2022|website=Tom’s Hardware}}</ref>
* Framedeck, a Framework [[motherboard]] based cyberdeck with clear acrylic and brass influenced by [[TRS-80 Model 100]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/brickbots/framedeck|title=brickbots/framedeck: A Framework mainboard based Cyberdeck|via=github.com|author=brickbots, Richard|access-date=May 16, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hackster.io/news/richard-sutherland-s-framedeck-is-a-trs-80-model-100-inspired-open-source-portable-pc-9937a2d73272|title=Richard Sutherland's Framedeck Is a TRS-80 Model 100 Inspired Open Source Portable PC|date=May 16, 2022|website=Hackster.io}}</ref>
* A tablet that uses Framework parts including the [[motherboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 22, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/framework-tablet-project/16690|title=Framework Tablet Project|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> Framework-Tablet, a 3D printable tablet case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/Framework-Tablet|title=whatthefilament/Framework-Tablet: 3D Printable Tablet Case for Framework Laptop|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=April 30, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/08/07/build-a-tablet-out-of-your-framework-motherboard/|title=Build A Tablet Out Of Your Framework Motherboard|date=August 7, 2022|website=Hackaday}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/framework-tablet-build/|title=Modder shows how to transform the Framework laptop into a tablet|date=August 8, 2022|website=PC Gamer}}</ref>
* FrameStation, a modern game console case for the Framework [[motherboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/FrameStation|title=whatthefilament/FrameStation: Game Console Case for Framework Motherboard|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=May 25, 2022}}</ref>
* Framework Desktop Case Adapter, a 3D printable mount to adapt a Framework [[motherboard]] to [[ATX]] and [[MicroATX]] motherboards and cases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/Framework-Desktop-Adapter|title=whatthefilament/Framework-Desktop-Adapter: Mounts to adapt Framework motherboard to ATX and Micro-ATX Motherboards and Cases|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=June 4, 2022}}</ref>

* An aluminum 3D-printed [[motherboard]] case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/dariusjlukas/aluminum-and-3d-printed-Framework-Case|title=dariusjlukas/aluminum-and-3d-printed-Framework-Case|via=github.com|author=dariusjlukas|access-date=February 1, 2023}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-2022-review" />

* DIY Triple Screen Laptop, a portable [[ergonomics]] computer with three screens (one panel, and two [[iPad]] [[Retina display|Retina displays]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://diyperks.com/diy-perks-triple-screen-laptop/|title=DIY Perks Triple Screen Laptop - DIY Perks|website=diyperks.com|author=DIY Perks|access-date=February 1, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|first=Chris|last=Person|date=January 31, 2023|url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/31/23580097/framework-laptop-triple-screen-diy-perks|title=Custom build turns the Framework Laptop into a triple-screen powerhouse|website=The Verge}}</ref>

=== Software ===

* Embedded Controller Modifications, an [[embedded controller|EC]] tool that changes the colors of LEDs and the keyboard layout on the firmware level, plus a suite of tools for talking to and manipulating the EC.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.howett.net/posts/2021-12-framework-ec|title=The Framework Laptop's Embedded Controller (EC)|website=www.howett.net|date=December 22, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_VrFXbRcHs8|title=Framework Holiday Lights|via=www.youtube.com|date=December 26, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=January 23, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/changed-my-keyboard-layout-in-hardware-to-colemak/14174|title=Changed my keyboard layout in hardware to colemak!|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/06/07/ec-hacking-your-laptop-has-a-microcontroller/|title=EC Hacking: Your Laptop Has A Microcontroller|date=June 7, 2022|first=Arsenijs|last=Picugins|website=Hackaday}}</ref>

=== Others ===

* Framework input cover controller, a [[RP2040]]-based controller for the palmrest, connecting to the keyboard matrix, touchpad, power button, fingerprint sensor [[LED]]s, keyboard backlight and CAPS LOCK [[LED]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/CRImier/MyKiCad/tree/master/Laptop%20mods/framework_input_controller|title=CRImier/MyKiCad: Framework input cover controller|via=github.com|author=CRImier, Ar|access-date=May 16, 2022}}</ref>
* Adjustable laptop stand<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5192872|title=Adjustable Framework Laptop Stand|via=www.thingiverse.com|author=Alexander - I_Mod_Things|access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-2022-review" />

== Support ==

{{primary sources|section|date=December 2021}}

The company supports by their [[knowledge base]] articles, community forum, QR codes on the products and parts, and inquiry form.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/support|title=Framework Support|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="pcmag" /> The company's customer support is controversial. It has both positive reviews that they are transparent, honest, and customer-focused<ref name=elevated-systems-6months-review /><ref name="linus-tech-tips-first-generation-rtc-battery" /> and negative reviews that they close the door.<ref name=linux-after-dark-19>{{Cite web|date=June 10, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fNRRiQSw-8&t=1280|title=Linux After Dark – Episode 19|author=Late Night Linux|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="twitter-framework-20220610" />

=== Supported countries and regions ===

Framework Laptop is available for order in the US, Canada, The UK, Germany, France, Ireland, The Netherlands and Austria. The company announced they will add additional countries in 2022, introducing their region selection page.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/what-countries-and-regions-do-you-ship-to-r1899ikiO|title=What countries and regions do you ship to?|website=knowledgebase.frame.work}}</ref><ref name="archyde-france">{{Cite web|date=December 17, 2021|url=https://www.archyde.com/framework-the-modular-pc-in-pre-order-for-france/|title=Framework: the modular PC in pre-order for France|website=www.archyde.com}}</ref> In December 2021, the company announced that they chose the additional supported countries UK, Germany and France based on both the number of people who registered interest through the region selection page and on logistical complexity.<ref name="frame.work-pre-order-uk-germany-france" /> In February 2022, pre-ordering became available for Ireland, Austria and The Netherlands.<ref name=":0" /> Pre-orders also opened in Australia in September 2022, with shipments arriving from October.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Buyck|first1=Marissa|title=Now available for pre-order in Australia|url=https://frame.work/au/en/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia|website=Framework Computers|access-date=2 September 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220902015449/https://frame.work/au/en/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia|archive-date=2 September 2022|language=en|date=1 September 2022|url-status=live}}</ref>

For people asking to buy Framework Laptop in their region,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://community.frame.work/t/what-countries-will-you-be-shipping-to/181|title=What countries will you be shipping to?|website=community.frame.work|date=March 30, 2021 }}</ref> the company recommended that they wait until the company officially launches in their region before ordering.<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 16, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/ordering-outside-us-using-shipping-forward/1644/2|title=Ordering outside US using shipping forward|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> The company mentioned that if an [[Package forwarding|import service]] was used, they would not be able to support the laptop or warranty.<ref>{{Cite web|date=December 6, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/is-it-a-foolish-endeavor-to-ship-a-laptop-from-the-usa-to-the-netherlands/11854/7|title=Is it a foolish endeavor to ship a laptop from the USA to the Netherlands?|website=community.frame.work}}</ref>

=== Linux ===

In December 2021, the company released a statement asking users who are not using Ubuntu 21.04.3+ or Fedora 35 to troubleshoot with Framework's [[Linux]] community<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://community.frame.work/c/diy-edition/linux/91|title=Linux topics - Framework Community|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> instead of contacting Framework support as no other [[Linux]] distribution has been verified by the company for hardware compatibility, mentioning that the company could troubleshoot general product usage issues on a supported OS, but could not troubleshoot OS related issues not related to the product functionality.<ref>{{Cite web|date=December 17, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/official-linux-and-framework-support-please-read/12435|title=OFFICIAL - Linux and Framework Support - PLEASE READ|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> In April 2022, the company announced their [[Linux]] compatibility page.<ref>{{Cite web|date=|url=https://frame.work/linux|title=Linux on the Framework Laptop|website=frame.work|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-mainboard" />

=== BSD operating systems ===

The company doesn't support [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]] operating systems. In June 2022, the [[FreeBSD Foundation]] announced their work to ensure that the experience running [[FreeBSD]] on the Framework Laptop matches the stability that [[FreeBSD]] users expect.<ref name="freebsd-newsflash">{{Cite web|url=https://www.freebsd.org/news/newsflash/|title=FreeBSD News Flash|website=www.freebsd.org|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref><ref name="freebsd-report-2022q1">{{Cite web|date=June 9, 2022|url=https://www.freebsd.org/status/report-2022-01-2022-03/|title=FreeBSD Quarterly Status Report First Quarter 2022|website=www.freebsd.org|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref>

== Electronics right to repair movement ==

[[File:Framework Laptop - the Design Museum.jpg|thumb|''Framework Laptop'' as part of the exhibition 'Waste Age: What can design do?' at ''the Design Museum''.]]

In June 2021, a [[venture capitalist]] investing in the company said "The conventional wisdom in the industry is that making products repairable makes them thicker, heavier, uglier, less robust, and more expensive. We’re here to prove that wrong and fix consumer electronics, one category at a time.".<ref name="anorak-post" /> In October 2021, the company said "The core problem is the idea that consumer electronics are disposable.",<ref name="bbc-newshour">{{Cite web|date=October 15, 2021|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p09yt773|title=BBC World Service - Newshour, Could manufacturers help reduce electronic waste?|website=BBC|access-date=June 5, 2022}}</ref> and "[[Right to repair]] is incredibly important. It is actually a core part of what we are doing. Because increasingly products are not designed to be repaired." in interviews.<ref name="freethink" />

Framework Laptop was on display as part of the Waste Age: What can Design Do? exhibition<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://designmuseum.org/exhibitions/waste-age-what-can-design-do|title=Waste Age: What can design do? - the Design Museum|website=designmuseum.org|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref> displayed at the Design Museum<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://designmuseum.org/|title=Design Museum|website=designmuseum.org|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref> in London from October 2021 to February 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|date=January 4, 2022|url=https://www.dailyimportant.thats.im/2022/01/04/framework-develops-modular-laptop-users-can-fix-and-upgrade-themselves/|title=Framework develops modular laptop users can fix and upgrade themselves|website=www.dailyimportant.thats.im|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref>
